Award.AwardTitle: Researching Pre-College Factors that Lead to Persistence in Computer Science
Award.AbstractNarration: This research project is studying the wide range of efforts underway nationwide to offer computer science (CS) and computational thinking (CT) to K-12 students, by measuring their impact on students' career interest in computer-related fields and on their attitudes toward computing. While there is widespread support for offering CS and CT experiences to pre-college students, there are few national statistics on the prevalence of in-school/out-of-school offerings, as well as personal hobbies and explorations. However great the enthusiasm about pre-college CS and CT initiatives, little definitive evidence exists about their long-term effects on students. Whereas many programs have been evaluated individually, the field has yet to examine the relative impact of pre-college students' CS and CT experiences on their interest in CS and STEM careers, their attitudes toward CS, and their CS identity. This study measures the impact of decisions about the use of computers and CT activities, made by CS and STEM teachers, as well as teachers of other subjects, along with those made by the creators of online resources, out-of-school time educators, and other involved professionals. This study has the capability to reveal the most promising educational practices and interventions (many developed with NSF support), including in-school computing and CT instruction, after-school programs, competitions, and clubs in a nationally representative sample of first-year college students. Because the under-representation of females and certain racial and ethnic minorities in the STEM and CS workforce has been a long-standing concern, this project will have a strong focus on girls and underrepresented minorities. It will determine both the degree to which these groups have access to the various CS and CT-related opportunities and the extent to which these opportunities translate into positive long-term outcomes for them.<br/><br/>Using epidemiological methods that control for prior interest and background variables, this retrospective cohort study will collect a nationally representative, stratified random sample of 8,000 college students (enrolled in a mandatory freshman course, so that students with all levels of interest and experience in CS and CT are included). It will model the degree to which any prior CS- and CT-related experiences predict students' CS attitudes, identity, and career interests, using linear and logistic regression. Epidemiological techniques offer a cost effective and well-understood methodology to simultaneously test multiple hypotheses, while controlling for a host of demographic and background factors that differ for individual subjects. This project is funded by the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to deepen insights into how various types and characteristics of precollege in-school and out-of-school time (OST) computer science (CS)-related activities and opportunities might strengthen CS interest, identity, and career interest. In addition, it investigated how such effects might differ by gender, race/ethnicity and intersectional groupings of gender and race/ethnicity.  

 

Using a random sampling of U.S. higher education institutions, we surveyed students enrolled in mandatory introductory English courses to obtain a diverse group of students, comprising those with, and without, CS career interests. A total of 6,044 students in 59 institutions completed the survey, which was administered by 210 instructors in the fall semester of 2021.

 

The survey inquired about students’ involvement in various CS-related in-school courses and activities, along with 27 distinct CS-related OST activities (both structured and unstructured) and opportunities within these activities. Additionally, students were questioned regarding their career interests at critical educational milestones: the beginning of middle school, the beginning of high school, the end of high school, and the beginning of college. The survey also explored the students’ CS identity as well as CS interest.

 

We found that the following activities during Grades 9-12 predicted students’ CS interest. Among in-school activities, these were taking robotics courses and more use of coding activity during the most advanced high school CS class. Among OST activities and opportunities, talking about CS with friends and families, writing computer programs, designing their own CS projects, and learning about CS career were all positively related with students’ CS interest. In addition, male students who talked about CS with friends and families, showed a higher increase in CS interest than did female students.

 

To measure students CS identity, we developed a single-item instrument, “I see myself as a computer science person,” (with a 6-point rating scale ranging from 0 = not at all to 5 = very much) and established its validity and reliability. We found that participating in the following activities during Grades 9-12 predicted students’ CS identity. Among in-school activities, taking CS courses, taking robotics courses, and a more frequent engagement in coding and non-coding activities during the most advanced high school CS class increased CS identity. Among OST activities and opportunities, talking about CS with friends and families, writing computer programs, designing their own CS project, working with older CS students, and learning about CS careers were all positively related with students’ CS identity. Moreover, male students showed a higher increase in their CS identity than did females when participating in writing computer programs and talking about CS with friends and family in high school.

 

We also found that participation in the following activities during Grades 9-12 increased the likelihood of a career interest in CS. Regarding in-school classes and activities, students who took robotics courses had a heightened interest in CS careers, compared to non-STEM careers. Furthermore, students who took two or more CS-related courses in high school were more likely to choose CS careers over other STEM careers. Regarding OST activities and opportunities, students who played computer games or talked about CS with friends and family, attended CS-related programs or summer camps, designed and carried out their own CS projects, or learned about CS careers during the high school years were more likely to have a career interest in CS at the beginning of college.

 

We further explored whether particular combinations of gender and race/ethnicity (e.g., White male, White female, Black male, and Black female) made a difference in how participation in either in-school and OST CS-related activities and opportunities affected CS interest, CS identity, or career interest in CS. No such differences were found.

 

In conclusion, the project yielded detailed insights into the types and characteristics of earlier in-school and OST activities and opportunities that were positively associated with students’ CS interest, identity, and career plans at the beginning of college. Additionally, the results revealed interactive effects between gender and students’ participation in in-school and OST activities and opportunities, informing targeted strategies for different genders. These results provide valuable guidance for in-school and OST providers and stakeholders who wish to strengthen students’ affinity to, and to broaden their participation in, CS-related fields.
